facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 171 of 1961 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 30, 1960 of the Allahabad High Court Lucknow Bench in Criminal Appeal No. 643 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 171 of 1961. Appeal by special leave from the Judgment and order dated January 30, 1960, of the Allahabad High Court  Lucknow Bench  at Lucknow in Criminal Appeal No. 643 of 1960.

facts.text: Special Judge West, Lucknow convicted the accused-respondent and sentenced him to one year's rigorous imprisonment under s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act No. II of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: who companyvicted the accused-respondent and sentenced him to one years rigorous imprisonment Under s. 5  2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act  No. II of 1947 , hereinafter called the Act.

facts.text: The respondent was a booking clerk at Saharanpur in the year 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent was a booking clerk at Saharanpur in the year 1955-56.

facts.text: Between October 22, 1955, and May 26, 1956, the respondent committed criminal breach of trust in respect of Rs. 49/1/0.

anchor.surface_text: Between October 22, 1955, and May 26, 1956, he companymitted criminal 74. breach of trust in respect of Rs. 49/1/0.

facts.text: The accused was sent up for trial before the Special Judge for offences under s. 5(1)(c) read with s. 5(2) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: On the said allegations the accused was sent up for trial before the Special Judge for offences under s. 5  1   c , read with s. 5  2 , of the Act.

facts.text: Before the Special Judge, prosecution filed 124 documents and examined 20 witnesses.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Special Judge the prosecution filed a number of documents numbering up to 124 and examined 20 witnesses.

facts.text: The accused admitted before the Special Judge that he had realized the amounts as alleged by the prosecution.

facts.text: The accused pleaded no dishonest intention and that the deficit was due to inadvertance and oversight.

facts.text: High Court set aside the conviction mainly on ground that Sub-Inspector Mathur made investigation before permission from Additional District Magistrate (Judicial), Lucknow.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the accused, the High Court set aside the companyviction mainly on the ground that the SubInspector Mathur made Investigation before he obtained the permission of the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial , Lucknow

anchor.surface_text: to investigate the case and as the said investigation was in violation of the provisions of the Act, the accused must be held to have been seriously prejudiced

facts.text: On April 26, 1956, A.N. Khanna, Railway Sectional Officer, Special Police Establishment, Lucknow, sent report to Superintendent of Police, SPE.

anchor.surface_text: On April 26, 1956, A.N. Khanna, the Railway Sectional Officer, Special Police Establishment, Lucknow, sent report to the Superintendent of Police, Special Police Establishment

facts.text: Khanna's report stated accused in habit of misappropriating Government money, giving 7 instances.

anchor.surface_text: stating that he had received information through a source that the accused was in the habit of misappropriating Government money, giving 7 instances of the acts

facts.text: Superintendent of Police directed Sub-Inspector Mathur to make an enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: Mathur, the Sub-Inspector of Police, Special Police Establishment, as P.W. 15 says that on the receipt of the said report, the said Superintendent of .Police directed him

facts.text: Mathur checked railway records, found information correct, submitted report.

anchor.surface_text: he further says that on the basis of the information he checked the railway records, found that the information was companyrect and submitted a report accordingly.

facts.text: On October 8, 1956, Sub-Inspector Mathur applied to Additional District Magistrate (Judicial), Lucknow for permission to investigate.

anchor.surface_text: After he submitted the report, on October 8, 1956, the said Sub-Inspector applied to the Additional District Magistrate  Judicial , Lucknow, for permission

facts.text: On October 19, 1956, the Magistrate permitted Sub-Inspector to investigate.

anchor.surface_text: On October 19, 1956, the said Magistrate permitted him to investigate.

facts.text: Thereafter, Sub-Inspector made further investigation, seized documents, took statements, submitted charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, he made further investigation, seized documents, took statements from witnesses and finally submitted a charge-sheet against the accused.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that enquiry by Mathur before permission was investigation within meaning of CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Sub- Inspector of the Police made investigation of the offence before obtaining the requisite permission of the Magistrate.

facts.text: Supreme Court sets aside High Court order, convicts respondent under s.5(2) POCA to 1 year RI.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the order of the High Court and companyvict the respondent under s. 5  2  of the Act and sentence him to one years rigorous imprisonment.

facts.text: Mudholkar J agrees with conviction but holds no defect in investigation as it was preliminary enquiry.

anchor.surface_text: I hold that what Mathur did was something very much short of investigation and, therefore, the provisions of s. 5A were number violated.

facts.text: State preferred present appeal against High Court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The State has preferred the present appeal against the said judgment of the High Court.

holdings.text: The Sub-Inspector of the Police made investigation of the offence before obtaining the requisite permission of the Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that the Sub- Inspector of the Police made investigation of the offence before obtaining the requisite permission of the Magistrate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied definition under CrPC s.4(1)(h) and Rishbud steps: received detailed information, proceeded to spot (railway station), ascertained facts by checking records, submitted report; distinguished preliminary vague enquiries.

holdings.text: Infringement of provisions of POCA s.5A in matter of investigation does not, without more, invalidate the trial.

anchor.surface_text: does the infringement of the salutary provisions of the Act in the matter of investigation, without more, invalidate the trial ? If we accept the broad proposition advanced by the learned counsel, we would be disregarding the provisions of s. 537 of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied CrPC s.537: irregularity does not vitiate unless prejudice; rejected presumption of prejudice from consistent disregard; must show nexus between irregularity and conviction or impaired defence.

holdings.text: The accused has not been prejudiced by the disregard of POCA s.5A in the first stage of investigation.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot, therefore, hold that the accused has been prejudiced by the illegality committed by the police in the first stage of the investigation, The High Court stt aside the conviction on the ground that there was a breach of the mandatory safe guards of the Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-permission investigation de novo and compliant; fair trial with 20 PW/124 exhibits; defence full opportunity (3 DW); Special Judge found guilt proved; no nexus or doubt on evidence manipulation.

holdings.text: High Court order set aside; respondent convicted under s.5(2) of POCA and sentenced to one year's rigorous imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, set aside the order of the High Court and convict the respondent under s. 5  2  of the Act and sentence him to one years rigorous imprisonment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court erred by not applying s.537 prejudice test; accepted Special Judge's finding on guilt via POCA s.5(1)(c)/5(2); evidence brought home misappropriation as public servant.

holdings.text: What Sub-Inspector Mathur did before permission was something very much short of investigation; provisions of s.5A not violated.

anchor.surface_text: I hold that what Mathur did was something very much short of investigation and, therefore, the provisions of s. 5A were not violated.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied Rishbud: discreet enquiries/checking records without arrest/questioning/search/statements/collection of trial evidence/no case diary; preliminary verification open pre-registration; no harassment defeating s.5A purpose.

holdings.text: Mere irregularity in investigation not ground for setting aside conviction unless accused prejudiced.

anchor.surface_text: I also agree that a mere irregularity in investigation would not be a ground for setting aside the conviction of an accused person unless the court is satisfied that the accused has been prejudiced by it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurs with majority on s.537 application; even if irregularity (contra his view), requires prejudice which absent.

precedents.citation: H.N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi  1

anchor.surface_text: H.N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. The State of Delhi  1 , described the procedure prescribed for investigation under Ch. XIV of the Code of Criminal Procedure thus Thus, under the Code investigation companysists generally of the following steps  1  Proceeding to the spot,  2  Ascertainment of the facts and circumstances of the case,  3  Discovery and arrest of the suspected offender,  4  Collection of evidence relating to the companymission of the offence which may companysist of  a  examination of various persons  including the accused  and the reduction of their statements into writing, if the officer thinks fit,  b  the search of places of seizure of things companysidered necessary for the investigation and to be produced at the trial, and  5  Formation of the opinion as to whether on the material companylected there is a case to place the accused before a M agistrate for trial and if so taking the necessary steps for the same by filing of a charge-sheet under section 173.

precedents.case_name: H.N. Rishbud and Inder Singh v. State of Delhi
precedents.cited_proposition: Definition and steps of investigation under Chapter XIV of the Code of Criminal Procedure
precedents.cited_holding: Investigation consists generally of: 1. Proceeding to the spot; 2. Ascertainment of facts; 3. Discovery and arrest; 4. Collection of evidence (examination, search, seizure); 5. Formation of opinion and filing charge-sheet.

anchor.surface_text: In re Nanumuri Anandayya a division Bench of the Madras High Court held that an informal enquiry on the. basis of a vague telegram was number an investigation within the meaning of s. 157 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

precedents.cited_proposition: Informal enquiry based on vague telegram is not investigation under s. 157 CrPC

anchor.surface_text: In In re Rangarajulu  2 , Ramaswami J., of the Madras A.I.R. 1915 Mad. 312.  2  A.I.R. 1958 Mad. 368, 371-372. High Court described the following three stages a policeman has to pass in a companyspiracy case hears something of interest affecting the public security and which puts him on the alert makes discreet enquiries, takes soundings and sets up informants and is in the second stage of qui vive or lookout and finally gathers sufficient information enabling him to bite upon something definite and that is the stage when first information is recorded and when investigation starts.

precedents.cited_proposition: Stages before investigation starts: alert, discreet enquiries on vague info, then formal investigation on definite info

precedents.citation: The State of Kerala v. M.J. Samuel  1

anchor.surface_text: In The State of Kerala v. M.J. Samuel  1 , a full Bench of the Kerala High Court ruled that,it can be stated as a general principle that it is number every piece of information however vague, indefinite and unauthenticated it may be that should be recorded as the First Information for the sole reason that such information was the first, in point of time, to be received by the police regarding the companymission of an offence.

precedents.case_name: State of Kerala v. M.J. Samuel
precedents.cited_proposition: Not every vague information needs to be recorded as FIR; depends on circumstances

precedents.citation: The State of Madhya Pradesh v. Mubarak Ali  1

anchor.surface_text: The scope of the said section and the reason underlying the said provision and others were companysidered by this Court in The State of Madhya Pradesh v. Mubarak Ali  1 . It was stated therein that s. 5A was inserted in the Act by Act 59 of 1952 to protect  1  1959 supp. 2 S. C. R. 201. public servants against harassment and victimization.

precedents.case_name: State of Madhya Pradesh v. Mubarak Ali
precedents.cited_proposition: Purpose of s.5A of Prevention of Corruption Act: protect public servants from harassment by requiring prior magisterial permission for investigation by lower officers
precedents.cited_holding: Statutory safeguards must be strictly complied with as conceived in public interest.

precedents.citation: H.N. Rishbud and lnder Singh v. The State q Delhi  1
